title: Oakland Plantation (Carvers, North Carolina)
text:
Oakland Plantation, situated on a bluff overlooking the <a href="Cape%20Fear%20River">Cape Fear River</a> in <a href="Carvers%2C%20North%20Carolina">Carvers</a>, <a href="Bladen%20County%2C%20North%20Carolina">Bladen County, North Carolina</a>, was built over 200 years ago by General Thomas Brown, an <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">American Revolutionary War</a> patriot. It is one of a few <a href="Plantation%20house%20in%20the%20Southern%20United%20States">house</a>s of its period in <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a> still being used today.
Listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>, Oakland depicts the architecture and skill of the artisans of that period. Bricks laid in <a href="Flemish%20bond">Flemish bond</a> were brought from England on sailing ships as <a href="Sailing%20ballast">ballast</a>, transported up river, and unloaded by hand.
It was added to the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> in 1972.
